On 25 January 2011, known as the "'''Day of Anger'''" ({{lang-ar|'''ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨'''}}, {{IPA-arz|ËjoËm elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|IPA}})<ref name="Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger"/> or the "Day of Revolt",<ref name="bbc25jan"/> protests took place in cities across Egypt, including [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], [[Suez]] and [[Ismailiya]].<ref name="bbc25jan"/> Thousands protested in Cairo, with 15,000 alone occupying [[Tahrir Square]];<ref name="Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|title=Egyptians Report Poor Communication Services on Day of Anger|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> 20,000 in various locations across Alexandria,<ref name="Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution">{{cite web|author=Manthorpe, Jonathan|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Egyptians+tests+Tunisia+Twitter+revolution/4168694/story.html|title=Egyptians Test Tunisia's Twitter Revolution|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> 200 demonstrators were in the southern city of [[Aswan]], 2,000 in the eastern city of Ismailiya; and about 3,000 in the northern city of [[Mahallah]].<ref name="Thousands protests in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Ahmed, Amir|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=Thousands Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>
On 25 January 2011, known as the "'''Day of Anger'''" ({{lang-ar|'''ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨'''}}, {{IPA-arz|ËjoËm elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|IPA}})<ref name="Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger"/> or the "Day of Revolt",<ref name="bbc25jan"/> protests took place in cities across Egypt, including [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], [[Suez]] and [[Ismailiya]].<ref name="bbc25jan"/> Thousands protested in Cairo, with 15,000 alone occupying [[Tahrir Square]];<ref name="Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|title=Egyptians Report Poor Communication Services on Day of Anger|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> 20,000 in various locations across Alexandria,<ref name="Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution">{{cite web|author=Manthorpe, Jonathan|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Egyptians+tests+Tunisia+Twitter+revolution/4168694/story.html|title=Egyptians Test Tunisia's Twitter Revolution|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> 200 demonstrators were in the southern city of [[Aswan]], 2,000 in the eastern city of Ismailiya; and about 3,000 in the northern city of [[Mahallah]].<ref name="Thousands protests in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Ahmed, Amir|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=Thousands Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Day of Anger riot police close.jpg|thumb|left|Paramilitary riot police of the [[Central Security Forces]] deployed during the 25 January protest]]
[[File:Day of Anger riot police close.jpg|thumb|left|Paramilitary riot police of the [[Central Security Forces]] deployed during the 25 January protest]]
â
Cairo protesters had gathered in the morning in front of the High Court in the centre of Cairo, within the framework of the activities of the protests taking place on [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. The demonstration was larger than usual and able to break the security cordon and head to [[Tahrir Square]]. A security official had been deploy more than 20,000 to 30,000 policemen in central Cairo, as police imposed a security cordon around a the Egyptian Interior Ministry building. Police used tear gas and water cannons against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836| title=Egypt Protests: Three Killed in 'Day of Revolt'| accessdate=26 January 2011| date=25 January 2011| work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> Deadly clashes broke out during the protests. A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters were killed.<ref name="bbc25jan"/> It was reported that many police had also been restrained in their use of violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70O2GG20110125?sp=true|title=Q+A-How Will Egypt's Protests Affect Mubarak's Rule?|work=[[Reuters]]|date=9 February 2009|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
+
Cairo protesters had gathered in the morning in front of the High Court in the centre of Cairo, within the framework of the activities of the protests taking place on [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. The demonstration was larger than usual and able to break the security cordon and head to [[Tahrir Square]]. A security official had been deploy more than 20,000 to 30,000 policemen in central Cairo, as police imposed a security cordon around a the Egyptian Interior Ministry building. Ordinary citizens joined the demonstrations that erupted in the capital and in the cities of Alexandria , Mansoura, Suez, Ismailia, Mahalla , Tanta and many other different places all over Egypt. Police used tear gas and water cannons against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836| title=Egypt Protests: Three Killed in 'Day of Revolt'| accessdate=26 January 2011| date=25 January 2011| work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> Deadly clashes broke out during the protests. A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters were killed.<ref name="bbc25jan"/> It was reported that many police had also been restrained in their use of violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70O2GG20110125?sp=true|title=Q+A-How Will Egypt's Protests Affect Mubarak's Rule?|work=[[Reuters]]|date=9 February 2009|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
{{clear}}
